title: 1 - Introduction
text:
Who are you?

You have intermediate R or Python knowledge
You can read data from CSV and other flat files, transform and reshape data, and make a wide variety of graphs
You can fit a model to data with your modeling framework of choice wide variety of graphs
You have exposure to basic modeling and machine learning practice
You do not need expert familiarity with advanced ML or MLOps topics

MLOps with vetiver

Vetiver, the oil of tranquility, is used as a stabilizing ingredient in perfumery to preserve more volatile fragrances.

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
Abalone ages


Age of abalone can be determined by cutting the shell and counting the number of rings through a microscope
Can other measurements be used to determine age?
Data from The Population Biology of Abalone (Haliotis species) in Tasmania. I. Blacklip Abalone (H. rubra) from the North Coast and the Islands of Bass Strait by Nash et al (1994)





library(tidyverse)
abalone <- read_csv("abalone.csv")



import pandas as pd
abalone = pd.read_csv("abalone.csv")

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
Abalone ages

N = 4177
A numeric outcome, rings
Other variables to use for prediction:
sex is a nominal predictor
shucked_weight and diameter are numeric predictors

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
Your turn üè∫

Explore the abalone data on your own!

What‚Äôs the distribution of the outcome, rings?
What‚Äôs the distribution of numeric variables like weight?
How do rings differ across sex?

Share something you noticed with your neighbor.



‚àí+
08:00




Make a plot or summary and then share with neighbor

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
ggplot(abalone, aes(rings)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 15)



This histogram brings up a concern. What if we split our data into training/testing and we get unlucky and sample few or none of these large values? That could mean that our model wouldn‚Äôt be able to predict such values. Let‚Äôs come back to that!

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
from plotnine import ggplot, aes, geom_boxplot, coord_flip
(ggplot(abalone, aes('sex', 'rings', fill='sex')) 
  + geom_boxplot(alpha=0.5, show_legend = False)
  + coord_flip()
)

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
abalone |>
  ggplot(aes(shucked_weight, rings, color = shell_weight)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  scale_color_viridis_c()

title: 1 - Introduction
text: Time for machine learning!

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
Spend your data budget
R

library(tidymodels)
set.seed(123)
ring_split <- initial_split(abalone, prop = 0.8, strata = rings)
ring_train <- training(ring_split)
ring_test <- testing(ring_split)

Python

from sklearn import model_selection
import numpy as np
np.random.seed(123)
X, y = abalone.iloc[:,:8], abalone['rings']
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = model_selection.train_test_split(
    X, y,
    test_size = 0.2
)

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
Fit a decision tree üå≥
Or your model of choice!
R

abalone_fit <-
  workflow(
    rings ~ ., 
    decision_tree(mode = "regression")
  ) |> 
  fit(data = ring_train) 

Python

from sklearn import preprocessing, tree, pipeline
le = preprocessing.OrdinalEncoder().fit(X_train)
tr = tree.DecisionTreeRegressor().fit(le.transform(X_train), y_train)
abalone_fit = pipeline.Pipeline([('label_encoder', le), ('decision_tree', tr)])

title: 1 - Introduction
text: Bind preprocessors and models together

text: What is wrong with this?

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
Create a deployable model object
R

library(vetiver)
v <- vetiver_model(abalone_fit, "abalone-rings-rstats")
v
#> 
#> ‚îÄ‚îÄ abalone-rings-rstats ‚îÄ <bundled_workflow> model for deployment 
#> A rpart regression modeling workflow using 8 features

Python

from vetiver import VetiverModel
v = VetiverModel(abalone_fit, "abalone-rings-python", ptype_data = X_train)
#> <string>:1: DeprecationWarning: argument for saving input data prototype has changed to prototype_data, from ptype_data
v.description
#> 'A scikit-learn Pipeline model'

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
pins üìå
The pins package publishes data, models, and other R and Python objects, making it easy to share them across projects and with your colleagues.







You can pin objects to a variety of pin boards, including:




a local folder (like a network drive or even a temporary directory)
Posit Connect
Amazon S3
Azure Storage
Google Cloud

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
Version your model
Learn about the pins package for Python and for R

PythonR



from pins import board_temp
from vetiver import vetiver_pin_write

board = board_temp(allow_pickle_read = True)
vetiver_pin_write(board, v)
#> Model Cards provide a framework for transparent, responsible reporting. 
#>  Use the vetiver `.qmd` Quarto template as a place to start, 
#>  with vetiver.model_card()
#> Writing pin:
#> Name: 'abalone-rings-python'
#> Version: 20230804T110225Z-08892




library(pins)

board <- board_temp()
board |> vetiver_pin_write(v)
#> Creating new version '20230804T150225Z-dfa3d'
#> Writing to pin 'abalone-rings-rstats'
#> 
#> Create a Model Card for your published model
#> ‚Ä¢ Model Cards provide a framework for transparent, responsible reporting
#> ‚Ä¢ Use the vetiver `.Rmd` template as a place to start

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
Version your model
R

library(pins)
board <- board_connect()
board |> vetiver_pin_write(v)

Python

from pins import board_connect
from vetiver import vetiver_pin_write
import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

api_key = os.getenv("CO_API_KEY")
rsc_url = os.getenv("CO_RSC_URL")

board = board_connect(server_url=rsc_url, api_key=api_key, allow_pickle_read = True)
vetiver_pin_write(board, v)

https://posit-conf-2023.github.io/vetiver

title: Deploy and maintain models with vetiver
text:
These are the materials for a one-day workshop on MLOps with vetiver on Monday, 18 Sept at posit::conf 2023!
Many data scientists understand what goes into training a machine learning or statistical model, but creating a strategy to deploy and maintain that model can be daunting. In this workshop, learn what MLOps (machine learning operations) is, what principles can be used to create a practical MLOps strategy, and what kinds of tasks and components are involved. We‚Äôll use vetiver, a framework for MLOps tasks in Python and R, to version, deploy, and monitor the models you have trained and want to deploy and maintain in production reliably and efficiently.

title: Deploy and maintain models with vetiver
text:
These are the materials for a one-day workshop on MLOps with vetiver on Monday, 18 Sept at posit::conf 2023!
Many data scientists understand what goes into training a machine learning or statistical model, but creating a strategy to deploy and maintain that model can be daunting. In this workshop, learn what MLOps (machine learning operations) is, what principles can be used to create a practical MLOps strategy, and what kinds of tasks and components are involved. We‚Äôll use vetiver, a framework for MLOps tasks in Python and R, to version, deploy, and monitor the models you have trained and want to deploy and maintain in production reliably and efficiently.

title: Deploy and maintain models with vetiver
text:
Is this workshop for me?
We expect participants to have exposure to basic modeling and machine learning practice, but NOT expert familiarity with advanced ML or MLOps topics. This workshop is for you if you:

have intermediate R or Python knowledge (this will be a ‚Äúchoose your own adventure‚Äù workshop where you can work through the exercises in either R or Python)
can read data from CSV and other flat files, transform and reshape data, and make a wide variety of graphs
can fit a model to data with your modeling framework of choice wide variety of graphs

title: Deploy and maintain models with vetiver
text:
Preparation
Please join the workshop with a computer that has the following installed:
tktk
Join us on GitHub Discussions to ask questions and share ideas.

title: Deploy and maintain models with vetiver
text:
Instructors
Julia Silge is a software engineer at Posit PBC focusing on open source MLOps tools, as well as an author and international keynote speaker. Julia loves making beautiful charts, Jane Austen, and her two cats.
Isabel Zimmerman is also a software engineer on the open source team at Posit PBC, where she works on building MLOps frameworks. When she‚Äôs not geeking out over new data science techniques, she can be found hanging out with her dog or watching Marvel movies.

title: Deploy and maintain models with vetiver
text:

This website, including the slides, is made with Quarto. Please submit an issue on the GitHub repo for this workshop if you find something that could be fixed or improved.

title: 2 - Deploy your model
text:
Fit a random forest üå≥üå¥üå≤üå≤üå¥üå≥üå¥üå≥üå≤

RPython



library(tidyverse)
library(tidymodels)
library(vetiver)
library(pins)
library(countdown)

abalone <- read_csv("abalone.csv")

set.seed(123)
ring_split <- initial_split(abalone, prop = 0.8, strata = rings)
ring_train <- training(ring_split)
ring_test <- testing(ring_split)

abalone_fit <-
  workflow(
    rings ~ ., 
    rand_forest(mode = "regression")
  ) |> 
  fit(data = ring_train) 




import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn import model_selection, preprocessing, ensemble, pipeline


abalone = pd.read_csv("abalone.csv")  

np.random.seed(123)
X, y = abalone.iloc[:,:8], abalone['rings']
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = model_selection.train_test_split(
    X, y,
    test_size = 0.2
)
le = preprocessing.OrdinalEncoder().fit(X_train)
rf = ensemble.RandomForestRegressor().fit(le.transform(X_train), y_train)
abalone_fit = pipeline.Pipeline([('label_encoder', le), ('random_forest', rf)])

title: 2 - Deploy your model
section: Create your vetiver model and version
text:
Create your vetiver model and version
R

library(vetiver)
library(pins)

v <- vetiver_model(abalone_fit, "abalone-rings-rstats")
board <- board_connect()
board |> vetiver_pin_write(v)

Python

from vetiver import VetiverModel, vetiver_pin_write
from pins import board_connect
import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()
api_key = os.getenv("CO_API_KEY")
rsc_url = os.getenv("CO_RSC_URL")

v = VetiverModel(abalone_fit, "abalone-rings-python", ptype_data = X_train)
board = board_connect(server_url=rsc_url, api_key=api_key, allow_pickle_read = True)
vetiver_pin_write(board, v)

REST API

title: 2 - Deploy your model
text:
What is a REST API?

An interface that can connect applications in a standard way

title: 2 - Deploy your model
text:
Create a vetiver REST API
R

library(plumber)

pr() |>
  vetiver_api(v) |>
  pr_run()

Python

api = VetiverAPI(v)
api.run()

text: What does ‚Äúdeploy‚Äù mean?

title: 2 - Deploy your model
text: What does ‚Äúdeploy‚Äù mean?

title: 2 - Deploy your model
text:
Deploy to Posit Connect
R

vetiver_deploy_rsconnect(board, "user.name/abalone-rings-rstats")

Python

from rsconnect.api import RSConnectServer
connect_server = RSConnectServer(url = rsc_url, api_key = api_key)

vetiver.deploy_rsconnect(
    connect_server = connect_server,
    board = board,
    pin_name = "user.name/abalone-rings-python",
)

title: 2 - Deploy your model
section: How do you make a request of your new API?
text:
How do you make a request of your new API?

RPython



url <- "https://colorado.posit.co/rsc/seattle-housing/metadata"
r <- httr::GET(url)
metadata <- httr::content(r, as = "text", encoding = "UTF-8")
jsonlite::fromJSON(metadata)
#> $user
#> list()
#> 
#> $version
#> [1] "77101"
#> 
#> $url
#> [1] "https://colorado.posit.co/rsc/content/bfb9a9c6-70da-4993-99dc-3559e9c8cdae/_rev77101/"
#> 
#> $required_pkgs
#> [1] "parsnip"   "ranger"    "workflows"




board.pin_meta("isabel.zimmerman/test_model").user

title: 2 - Deploy your model
section: How do you make a request of your new API?
text:
How do you make a request of your new API?

Python or R packages like requests or httr (or httr2!)
curl
There is special support in vetiver for the /predict endpoint

title: 2 - Deploy your model
text:
Create a vetiver endpoint
You can treat your model API much like it is a local model in memory!
R
## TODO: put a model on Colorado with our dataset and run this for real
endpoint <- vetiver_endpoint("https://connect.example.com/content/$APP_ID/predict")
predict(endpoint, slice_sample(ring_test, n = 10))
Python
## TODO: put a model on Colorado with our dataset and run this for real
from vetiver.server import predict, vetiver_endpoint
endpoint = vetiver_endpoint(f"https://connect.example.com/content/{APP_ID}/predict")
predict(endpoint = endpoint, data = ring_test)

What if your model API requires authentication?
R
## TODO: put a model on Colorado with our dataset and run this for real
endpoint <- vetiver_endpoint("https://connect.example.com/content/$APP_ID/predict")
predict(endpoint, slice_sample(ring_test, n = 10))
Python
## TODO: put a model on Colorado with our dataset and run this for real
from vetiver.server import predict, vetiver_endpoint
endpoint = vetiver_endpoint(f"https://connect.example.com/content/{APP_ID}/predict")

title: 2 - Deploy your model
text:
Create a vetiver endpoint
What if your model API requires authentication?
R
endpoint <- vetiver_endpoint("https://connect.example.com/content/$APP_ID/predict")
apiKey <- Sys.getenv("CONNECT_API_KEY")
predict(endpoint, slice_sample(ring_test, n = 10), 
        httr::add_headers(Authorization = paste("Key", apiKey)))
Python
from vetiver.server import predict, vetiver_endpoint

endpoint = vetiver_endpoint(f"https://connect.example.com/content/{APP_ID}/predict")
h = { 'Authorization': f'Key {api_key}' }
predict(endpoint = endpoint, data = ring_test, headers = h)
